title: So Rengar...? @Meddler
body: I saw a post of yours (Meddler) a little while ago that said Rengar will more than likely be getting looked at when it comes time for the next class update (Assassins, Diving fighters, etc...which ever it may be). Now that you released the class and subclass categories with the champions put into their respective classes, how do you see Rengar being changed. Rengar was listed as a Slayer -> Assassin. So do you see him keeping this title? If so what do you see as potential changes. I like to play the champion, and I'm curious to know what I should expect from any future updates.

replies.body:
> assassin at present

Rengar represents a lesson not learned by riot: The lesson of original Eve. Burst and CC, from stealth, from a character with ultra high range and dependable "reach" on the win condition characters of the other team. You nerfed eve for it; then you made rengar with the exact same idea. 

As it is he's an excellent diver with limited fallback patterns or follow-up moves. Not quite good enough at skirmishing to be capable of limiting return damage or sticking post his initial through mobility and evasion, and not healthy enough due to his signature move to be given adequate burst. 

Rengar is the people's favorite: probably because what assassin players seek in a character is a "delete" button for the player on the other team and rengar, when he is strong, provides reliabely. Nonetheless - a bad design.

Yep, Rengar's got some problems on his kit that ideally we'd have avoided based off past experience. The intent with his design was for much longer combat/kill times to avoid those issues, that didn't work out as desired however, leading to some extremely low times to live for his targets from the start of the engagement to the end (for them at least).

I do think it's important to call out the positives on Rengar as well though. His kit has issues, but some really good stuff as well (Brush passive changing how/where he wants to fight, Ferocity usage, coherence of theme and gameplay etc).

That does not change the unholy fusion of two design components that should never be fused: Burst and Stealth. 
Evelynn has been pushed more towards being an AD DPS assassin and Twitch was always supposed to DPS. This thing works because it gives you time to react to the suddenly emerging threat that you literally did not see coming. 

Rengar however is always in this limbo of being either super obnoxious or super useless. 
What happens when he is super obnoxious is what we could see during his 4 week long reign throughout all elos in preseason 6. Possibly the most horrible 4 weeks i have ever experienced in League.

to be fair, "tank 0-damage rengar" saw quite a lot of competitive play.

Specifically as a combo-enabler....

...but i suppose most rengar players want to insta gib, rather than "play tank".

Strong or not, I also think Rengar is a huge problem, he being on the opposing team is probably the worst thing in LoL for me. Any counterplay is non-existent, he's horrible to play against even for an assassin. 

It's boggling how there's unbelievable burst and super high sustained damage on the same character, as well as high tankyness AND a heal. He's got all the strengths and none of the weaknesses of an Assassin AND a Diver.

Even if you somehow flashes away before he leap-deletes you he has a root to catch you AGAIN. He's a horrible experience, certainly when he's strong and even when he is not. (Sorry if I'm being hyperbolic, that's just my experience.)

On paper though, I think his Brush passive is the most interesting thing on the kit, although I think the sharpness of it is undermined by putting the same leap on the ult, so there's not really anywhere he doesn't like to fight when he needs to (especially since he doesn't have to fight for long, he just deletes people..). There's so many other mechanics on the ult already so I don't know why the unconditional leap had to be put on there too. It'd be more sharp/interesting, and probably healthier, to put some of that power into the brush-passive instead.

The "!" warning you get for a second or two is certainly not enough to have a chance to respond, given that there's no way to escape or stop him from getting to you from miles away, anyway.

If you disagree on any of my comments I'd love to hear your counter-arguments, though, haha. Although I'm just talking about the Rengar we know, not the "ideal" design-version of him. Those two are certainly different beasts...

Stop playing with a solo mind-set against him and work as a team for crying out loud. Instead of being selfish and picking your favorite champion (good lord at the amount of yasuo's I've stomped top in past), pick things that can make it more difficult from completing his job. Top: Maokai, malphite, Shen, Lulu, Wukong; Mid: Azir, Kayle, Lulu, Twisted Fate, Zilean, Zyra; Adc: any with mobility but it still depends on your team's effort in protecting. It may be fun for the Rengar when there's no options to play against him, but the entire game suffers for it, so it'd be childish to demand him not changing. Most assassins actually lets you be relativelly safe SOMEWHERE outside the fountain, Rengar does not. Unrivaled initiation and less than a second to kill is not okay or manageable at most skill levels, even with backup.

I agree with you somewhat, since i've mained rengar on my main account and I know almost all the ins and outs of the kitty. Though rengar is capable to delete ADC's in 1-4 seconds' time, there is so much delicate and complex combos at work. It took months, maybe even years for rengar mains throughout the world to craft builds, adapt every patch, and the one shot combo itself was created. You charge up your 5 fero Q, mid-air you cast your E (which riot made it tons harder to land mid air) and W-Hydra both at the same time to cancel the W animation. Though I agree with riot that rengar needs work, I just want them to know to not waste and throw away the 4-year long work of people who strived to make the champion better and even overpowered. Rework him, do not completely scrap his kit. Heck, if not for the dedicated rengar mains Dekar and Ryan Choi, almost no one would even play Rengar after his nerf since alot viewed the champion trash post-rework. I do not hold control and I am just stating my (biased?) opinion. I will continue to support Reng as a champ after the rework, as a true rengar main I will stick to him through all the good and the bad.

TLDR: If riot rework rengar, do not completely scrap all of his abilities and possibly only leave his Q, and his brush passive.

I can see how the ferocity management, especially with the Q, is appealing. The problem is how several instant empowered attack-resets creates such massive and quick burst when the combo is executed; the input is great, the output is the issue. 

There's no reason to remove the combo per say, but the way damage is dealt itself should be entirely changed, imho, such that it is dealt over a longer window. The AS component is a failed attempt at this, as it stands. 

Either way, do you think it would ruin the feeling of the ability by removing the attack-timer reset and making it an on-next-attack? I suspect it might.
I don't think a DoT would be a good solution, because it's less visceral relative to it's power.
Some other delayed damage might work; perhaps Q JUST giving attack speed, or Q applying a delayed mark that can be popped by an auto a second or two later. 

Alternatively, I could see it being more justified to have somewhat high burst if his initiation was less reliable. IDK.

That's the tough issue with assassins that have such reliable leaps; it's hard to make abilities that can be dodged or otherwise played against when the assassin reliably get right on top of someone. Even with a fractional second where you can flash away, it's really tough for him to miss E or W when Rengar is already right on top of someone. Unintuitively, ranged assassins are often healthier designs for this reason, imo.

I might be wrong but what is causing Rengar to be the primary target of complaints is he's stealth plus the fact that he can one shot anyone who isn't a tank. Most player will buy the oracle's lens or a pink ward to try and see where he's coming from but those two inform you, in many cases, when it is already too late !
One healthy and simple way to introduce some counterplay to that would be to implement a new element to Rengar ult: a sort of compass on everyone in the enemy team, that would look like Fiora's ult for example, and that would tell you:
1. When Rengar used it's stealth (it is a really long range stealth and it could give you enough time to group up). Sion, Reksai, TF all have a way to tell you that something is going on far away from you and that it is coming towards you very fast to kill you. Rengar definitely fits in that category
2. Tell you approximatly from where the danger is coming. A NSEW kind of radar. Might even add a color to it to tell you if he's far away or really close (so you can start dropping wards/oracles) but I am not sure if this would completely kill Rengar or not.. So, yes to the compass, maybe for the range indicator.

In addition he needs to have Youmuus fully built to engage on someone without them having a decent while to react. Finally the problem with Eve is that she was constantly in stealth. She was a pretty good early jungler where as Rengar's early jungle clears are so bad and his early ganks pre-6 will be almost nonexistent.

Don't compare him to old Eve.

You put it super well, much better than I do, mostly because of my version would be colored by a lot of frustration at this point, haha.

A reliable leap and stealth just doesn't mix, as you say; it's telling that diver-Evelynn is the only version that has been allowed to stick around without being gutted. I also think time has shown the "!"-warning hasn't been enough of a drawback to create any meaningful counterplay. 

Just looking at the ult in general there's just SO much stuff on it, compared to other similar champions. It's especially weird because in a dueling scenario Rengar packs quite the punch even without his ult. 

In the end, it feels like someone put a lot of cool mechanics on Rengar (passive, ult-vision) and then ruined it by making him so reliably powerful that he didn't really have to play around any of those mechanics to succeed.

We see Rengar as more of an assassin at present, hence that classification. Lot of discusison though as to whether a healthier Rengar would be closer to a diver or skirmisher. I think it's likely we'll work on Rengar for the end of year class update, can't speak with any confidence about direction until we've had some time to prototype and test some things though.

So does he actually have a fixed month rather than a fixed date?

Our projects have estimated release patches. Those can change though, based off work going at a different speed than expected, priorities changing, unexpected bugs or balance problems etc. That means we've got estimates even for champs like Warwick who are quite a long way off, they're very much a best attempt at a prediction though rather than a certainty.

We have arbitrary deadlines we need to fill. Those can change on a whim though because my boss has no clue what hes doing and this is first job. Honestly half the time we spend on these projects is fixing past mistakes and redoing things that we could have forseen had we put any thought into it at all. We do however prioritize champions not based on need for rework but instead by size of their dedicated player base. This means we can push warwick out into the statosphere while we rework rengar for the 3rd time.

So let's say assassins are selected to be the next roster update, and Rengar is on the list, but you decide he would be more of a fighter/diver than assassin, because that's a better space for him or whatever.

Would you make someone a better diver during an assassin update?

I asked this about Diana in another thread, but I'm just curious what you think.

I could see us looking at Rengar in a Diver or Assassin update. We do want to keep focus on one class of champions at a time, given it allows us to focus a team on a shared set of design problems and enables item etc supporting work too. Some exceptions are ok there though if they're in a similar space and taking advantage of those learnings/systems.
How does this impact the hard to categorize champions? Does it make it harder to find time to work on an Urgot or a Kennen?

A large part of these class updates is focused on making champions more distinct from others that do similar things. Hard to categorize champs don't tend to have issues in that regard. Some of them do have bigger functionality and/or game health issues (Hi Urgot), that'll tend to make them good choices for full updates though so they'll get caught in that alternative workflow instead.

Translation:
 
We want every champion to feel special. Sort of like a snowflake. Champions that we don't have any clue on how to fix because we already messed them up to begin with will just get a full rework that will be so huge that you might as well call them by a different name. We realize that when we do this about half the people maining those champions hate everything we did to them and the other half just play the champion regardless of how different and unfun it feels. We realize that, but we still have deadlines and bosses who are so out of touch with the community they might as well live on the moon and communicate by birdmail.

We will probably completely change Rengar due to our bosses sudden need for a class system even though we are 6 years into the game's life cycle and that has never been a real priority for anyone but the people who keep saying they designed the game. We are sort of sorry for this but we never really liked Rengar in the first place because he wasn't quite flashy enough to justify the complete and utter domination of top lane. We either will make him unable to dominate at all or make him more flashy. Certainly true damage though.
